metadata.title: Management of COVID-19 in patients after liver transplantation: Beijing working party for liver transplantation

body_text.text: The pathogen causing a “mysterious” pneumonia in Wuhan, Hubei, since December 2019, has been identified as a novel coronavirus [1]. The World Health Organization (WHO) named this virus the 2019 new coronavirus (2019-nCoV) and the new coronavirus pneumonia as COVID-19. COVID-19 has been included in the Class B infectious diseases stipulated in the Law of the People's Republic of China on the Prevention and Control of Infectious Diseases, and is managed as a Class A infectious disease [1].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The COVID-19 epidemic has spread rapidly in China and other countries worldwide. With effective measures, the number of new cases in China has decreased significantly. However, with the sharp increase in other countries, imported cases increase markedly in China.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Early diagnosis, early quarantine, and early treatment are important in COVID-19 prevention and control. Understanding its biological characteristics and clinical manifestations is crucial to set up proper guidelines [2]. This article summarized recent relevant publications and put forward recommendations for management of liver transplantation during COVID-19 epidemic period.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: 2019-nCoV is a single-stranded positive-strand RNA, beta-type coronaviruses. It has four major structural proteins, namely fibrillin (S), envelope protein (M), small envelope protein (E), and nuclear protein (N). The initial attachment to the host cell is via binding of S protein to ACE2 receptor on host cell membrane [3].
body_text.section: 2019-nCoV and its pathogenesis

body_text.text: 2019-nCoV is sensitive to ultraviolet rays and heat. It can be inactivated by ether, 75% alcohol, 56 °C for 30 min, and chlorine-containing disinfectant, chloroform [1]. The main transmission routes are droplet transmission and mucosal contact transmission [4]. There is also the possibility of aerosol transmission after exposure to high concentrations of aerosol in a relatively closed environment for long period. 2019-nCoV nucleic acid sequences can be detected in patients' eye secretions and feces, but whether transmission can occur remains to be confirmed [4]. 2019-nCoV infects all age groups, particularly the elderly and those with underlying diseases [4]. Organ transplant recipients are susceptible population.
body_text.section: 2019-nCoV and its pathogenesis

body_text.text: Whether organ transplantation should be carried out during the COVID-19 epidemic remains controversial [1, 4]. Due to the unknown risks, some experts suggested that transplantation should be suspended. Alternatively, the recently released guidance [4] suggested that transplantation surgery could be carried out after careful risk assessments.
body_text.section: 2019-nCoV and its pathogenesis

body_text.text: The incubation period of 2019-nCoV infection is 1–14 days, mostly 3 to 7 days. Transmission can occur during the incubation period [1]. There is no evidence that the incubation period in liver transplant recipients is different.
body_text.section: Incubation period ::: Clinical characteristics of COVID-19 in liver transplant recipients

body_text.text: Fever is the first symptom of 2019-nCoV infection in most patients. However, in organ transplant recipients, there may be only low-grade fever or no fever at all [2]. Therefore, transplant physicians cannot relax their vigilance in afebrile patients [1, 2].
body_text.section: Fever ::: Clinical manifestations ::: Clinical characteristics of COVID-19 in liver transplant recipients

body_text.text: Dry cough is the main clinical manifestation of COVID-19 in the general population and transplant recipients [1, 5].
body_text.section: Dry cough ::: Clinical manifestations ::: Clinical characteristics of COVID-19 in liver transplant recipients

body_text.text: Loss of smell and taste has been observed in many COVID-19 patients.
body_text.section: Loss of smell and taste, and other symptoms ::: Clinical manifestations ::: Clinical characteristics of COVID-19 in liver transplant recipients

body_text.text: Due to the immuno-suppressive state, COVID-19 may progress rapidly to acute ARDS in transplant recipients [1, 5].
body_text.section: Loss of smell and taste, and other symptoms ::: Clinical manifestations ::: Clinical characteristics of COVID-19 in liver transplant recipients

body_text.text: Other common symptoms include fatigue, anorexia, nausea, nasal congestion, sore throat, myalgia, and diarrhea.
body_text.section: Loss of smell and taste, and other symptoms ::: Clinical manifestations ::: Clinical characteristics of COVID-19 in liver transplant recipients

body_text.text: The imaging findings of COVID-19 have common features with other viral pneumonia. Multiple small patchy shadows and interstitial changes with prominent extrapulmonary bands appear in early phase. Multiple ground-glass shadows, infiltrates, and lung consolidation occur during the progress phase. Pleural effusion is rare. Chest CT is the recommended imaging procedure. Compared with the general population, liver transplant recipients have more extensive lung lesions, multiple lesions, and more lower lobes involvement [1, 6].
body_text.section: Imaging findings ::: Clinical characteristics of COVID-19 in liver transplant recipients

body_text.text: Leucocyte count is normal or low. Lymphopenia is common. Some patients have elevated liver enzymes, muscle enzymes, myoglobin, and lactate dehydrogenase. Most have elevated C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Severe and critically ill patients are more likely to have elevated D-dimers, progressive lymphopenia, and increase in inflammatory markers [1, 5].
body_text.section: Laboratory tests ::: Clinical characteristics of COVID-19 in liver transplant recipients

body_text.text: In the 14 days before illness onsetHistory of residence in or entry and exit from a country with documented COVID-19 cases orHistory of residence or visits to Wuhan and surrounding areas orHistory of contact with COVID-19 patients orContact with patients with fever or respiratory symptoms from countries with case reports of COVID-19 orContact with patients with fever or respiratory symptoms from Wuhan and surrounding orResidence or work in areas of suspected COVID-19 outbreaks (for example, two or more cases in the same building, school, or office).
body_text.section: Epidemiological history ::: Suspected case ::: Diagnosis of COVID-19 in liver transplant recipients

body_text.text: Fever or respiratory symptoms.Normal or decreased leucocyte counts: lymphopenia.One or more of the imaging characteristics described in Sect. 2.3.
body_text.section: Clinical manifestation ::: Suspected case ::: Diagnosis of COVID-19 in liver transplant recipients

body_text.text: COVID-19 is confirmed ifReal-time fluorescent RT-PCR detection of 2019-nCoV nucleic acid is positive orGene sequences from patient’s specimen and 2019-nCoV are highly homologous orSerum 2019-nCoV-specific IgM antibodies and IgG antibodies are positive (IgG seroconversion or there is a fourfold increase from baseline).
body_text.section: Confirmation of suspected case ::: Diagnosis of COVID-19 in liver transplant recipients

body_text.text: COVID-19 is excluded if two consecutive tests of 2019-nCoV nucleic acid (sampling time at least 24 h apart) are negative, and 2019-nCoV-specific IgM/IgG antibodies are still negative after 7 days of onset.
body_text.section: Confirmation of suspected case ::: Diagnosis of COVID-19 in liver transplant recipients

body_text.text: 2019-nCoV nucleic acid detection is performed in nasopharyngeal swabs, sputum, other lower respiratory tract secretions, blood, stool, and urine. Lower respiratory tract specimens (sputum or airway extracts) are preferred. Specimens should be submitted to testing centers as soon as possible after collection to maximize detection rates [1].
body_text.section: Confirmation of suspected case ::: Diagnosis of COVID-19 in liver transplant recipients

body_text.text: Infections with influenza virus, adenovirus, respiratory syncytial virus, cytomegalovirus, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Pneumocystis carinii, and other pathogens must be ruled out.
body_text.section: Differential diagnosis ::: Diagnosis of COVID-19 in liver transplant recipients

body_text.text: 2019-nCoV testing is recommended in symptomatic liver transplant recipient with COVID-19 epidemiological history, even if the tests for common respiratory pathogens are positive [1, 2].
body_text.section: Differential diagnosis ::: Diagnosis of COVID-19 in liver transplant recipients

body_text.text: Liver dysfunction is observed in up to 50% of COVID-19 patients [5, 7], mainly hepatocellular pattern, usually mild and resolves in 2–3 weeks. If a liver transplant recipient develops cholestatic liver injury or liver function deteriorates rapidly, other etiologies must be excluded before attributing to COVID-19.
body_text.section: Differential diagnosis ::: Diagnosis of COVID-19 in liver transplant recipients

body_text.text: Liver transplant recipients and their family members in the same household should abide by the travel advisories issued by their government agencies and cancel unnecessary trips. Avoid travel on cruise ships and to places with 2019-nCoV outbreaks.All patients who have returned from countries with COVID-19 should contact the transplant centers by phone or electronic messages regarding follow-up arrangements.
body_text.section: Travel advice ::: Prevention of CoVID-19 ::: Management of liver transplant recipients during 2019-nCoV epidemics

body_text.text: Telemedicine is preferred over face-to-face consultations to avoid cross-infection during hospital visits.
body_text.section: Hospital visits ::: Prevention of CoVID-19 ::: Management of liver transplant recipients during 2019-nCoV epidemics

body_text.text: Recommendations:Reduce the frequency of examinations and imaging as much as possible.If blood tests or imaging is required, perform them at a low-risk hospital or have blood samples taken at low-risk centers and then deliver to the relevant hospital.Telemedicine if possible.
body_text.section: Hospital visits ::: Prevention of CoVID-19 ::: Management of liver transplant recipients during 2019-nCoV epidemics

body_text.text: Regular exercise at home:regular meals, avoid cold food, raw seafood and wild animals;regular sleep schedule.Pay attention to hand hygiene; wash hands frequently; wear a mask when going out; avoid contact with patients with cough, fever, or infectious diseases; keep social distancing; regularly disinfect the environment.Check body temperature daily.Contact transplant centers promptly if develop fever and respiratory symptoms.
body_text.section: Personal hygiene and lifestyle ::: Prevention of CoVID-19 ::: Management of liver transplant recipients during 2019-nCoV epidemics

body_text.text: Recipients should be placed in single isolation rooms with bathroom facilities.
body_text.section: Transplant center setup ::: Prevention of CoVID-19 ::: Management of liver transplant recipients during 2019-nCoV epidemics

body_text.text: Close liaison with auxiliary departments such as radiology department so that the liver transplant recipients are separated in time and space from other patients.
body_text.section: Transplant center setup ::: Prevention of CoVID-19 ::: Management of liver transplant recipients during 2019-nCoV epidemics

body_text.text: Reviewing the reports published on SARS, MERS, and COVID-19, no mention is made on immunosuppression as a risk factor for mortality, and no fatality is reported to be linked to transplantation or other conditions requiring immunosuppressive treatment. Risk factors for poor outcome include advanced age, male sex, and presence of comorbidities [8–10].
body_text.section: Transplant team ::: Prevention of CoVID-19 ::: Management of liver transplant recipients during 2019-nCoV epidemics

body_text.text: Recommendations:Treat any liver transplant candidate or recipient presenting with epidemiology history or clinical manifestations mentioned in Sect. 3.1 as suspected case.Wear complete personal protective equipment during patient’s care until 2019-nCoV infection is excluded.Should self-quarantine after unprotected contact with a confirmed or suspected case until COVID-19 is excluded.
body_text.section: Transplant team ::: Prevention of CoVID-19 ::: Management of liver transplant recipients during 2019-nCoV epidemics

body_text.text: Currently, there is limited information on the impact of 2019-nCoV on patients with chronic hepatitis B infection, chronic liver disease, with decompensated liver cirrhosis or transplant candidates on waiting list.
body_text.section: Evaluation of potential liver transplant recipients and patients on transplant waiting list ::: Management of liver transplant recipients during 2019-nCoV epidemics

body_text.text: Recommendations:Follow measures mentioned in Sect. 4.1 to reduce the risk of 2019-nCoV infection.Prescribe enough basic medicines such as antiviral drugs for 2–3 months to reduce visits.Avoid consulting potential liver transplant recipients or donors at liver clinic if they have fever and respiratory symptoms.Living donation should not be performed on either a donor or recipient who has returned from countries with COVID-19 outbreaks or who have been exposed to confirmed or suspected COVID-19 within 14 days. Donors should not be considered if they have fever and/or respiratory symptoms unless 2019-nCoV is excluded.
body_text.section: Evaluation of potential liver transplant recipients and patients on transplant waiting list ::: Management of liver transplant recipients during 2019-nCoV epidemics

body_text.text: Currently, it is unclear whether transplant recipients are more likely to develop more severe COVID-19. Only one case of fatal SARS [11] in liver transplant recipient is reported and none with MERS. As for 2019-nCoV, an experience in Bergamo shows that three of two hundred transplant recipients were tested positive for 2019-nCoV [10]. It is well known that immunocompromised people were susceptible to viral infection. However, immunosuppressed patients > 60 years of age are at higher risk of infection with 2019-nCoV, and may have prolonged virus clearance [1, 5].
body_text.section: Management of COVID-19 liver transplant recipients ::: Management of liver transplant recipients during 2019-nCoV epidemics

body_text.text: Recommendations:Follow measures mentioned in Sect. 4.1 to reduce risk of 2019-nCoV infection.No need to adjust the dose of immunosuppressive drugs.Emphasize preventive measures mentioned in Sect. 4.1.Transplant patients with fever and/or respiratory symptoms should inform the transplant centers promptly and avoid unscheduled visit to the clinic avoid inadvertent exposures.
body_text.section: Management of COVID-19 liver transplant recipients ::: Management of liver transplant recipients during 2019-nCoV epidemics

body_text.text: Currently, the impact of immunosuppressant on COVID-19 is unclear, and the recommendations for SARS/MERS are not validated because of short epidemic durations with limited cases. The potential role of corticosteroids in preventing mild COVID-19 from developing into severe pneumonia is controversial. WHO recommends avoiding the use of corticosteroids while treatment protocols in China recommend use for a short period of time in patients with rapid disease progression and evidence of marked inflammations. Also, there is concern that reducing or discontinuing immunosuppressant may cause acute graft rejection [1, 2]. EASL-ESCMID position paper advises against immunosuppressive therapy reduction [12].
body_text.section: Immunosuppressive regimens in liver transplant recipients with COVID-19 ::: Management of liver transplant recipients during 2019-nCoV epidemics

body_text.text: Recommendations:No need to adjust the dose of immunosuppressive drugs in transplant recipients without COVID-19.For patients with mild to moderate COVID-19, keep current immunosuppressant dosage and monitor patient’s condition closely. Avoid prescription of medications that cause large fluctuations in tacrolimus plasma concentrations.For patients with severe or rapidly progressing COVID-19, reduce the amount of calcineurin inhibitor and consider stopping anti-metabolic drugs.If decided to reduce the dose of steroids, keep at least a daily dose of 10 mg prednisone or equivalence to avoid adrenal insufficiency.Corticosteroids or other immunosuppressive therapies can be re-initiated with caution when the potential benefits outweighing their risks of discontinuation.
body_text.section: Immunosuppressive regimens in liver transplant recipients with COVID-19 ::: Management of liver transplant recipients during 2019-nCoV epidemics

body_text.text: The results of randomized controlled trials showed that lopinavir/ritonavir did not show clinical benefit in patients with severe COVID-19, and in some patients, treatment were discontinued early due to adverse drug reactions [13]. Lopinavir/ritonavir is a potent inhibitor of CYP3A4 and tacrolimus dose should be significantly reduced if lopinavir/ritonavir is used. Animal studies have shown that ACEI and ARB can prevent severe pulmonary complications caused by COVID-19, and no data are available in humans. The European College of Cardiology Hypertension Committee recommends that patients with COVID-19 should continue to receive conventional antihypertensive treatment, including ACEI and ARB drugs.
body_text.section: COVID-19 therapy and potential drug interactions in liver transplant recipients ::: Management of liver transplant recipients during 2019-nCoV epidemics

body_text.text: Recommendations:The current evidence does not support the use of lopinavir/ritonavir in liver transplant recipients with COVID-19.Continue the use of ACEI and ARB.Use of traditional Chinese medicine therapy without evidence-based data is not recommended.Do not stop or adjust the immunosuppressive regimen without consulting the doctors.Avoid medicines that have an impact on immunosuppressive drug concentrations.
body_text.section: COVID-19 therapy and potential drug interactions in liver transplant recipients ::: Management of liver transplant recipients during 2019-nCoV epidemics
